name: Take On Helicopters
description: The brand new helicopter game from independent developers Bohemia Interactive – creators of the award-winning military-Sim series Arma 2. Built upon over 10 years of experience in cutting-edge simulator development, Take On Helicopters immerses players within beautifully rich landscapes and an authentic flight model.
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows XP Processor:Intel Dual-Core 2.4 GHz or AMD Dual-Core Athlon 2.5 GHz or faster Memory:2 GB RAM Graphics:NVIDIA GeForce 8800GT or ATI Radeon 4850 with Shader Model 3 and 512 MB VRAM or faster DirectX®:dx90c Hard Drive:20 GB HD space Sound:DirectX 9.0c compatible audio-card
recommended_requirements: OS:Windows Vista, Windows 7 Processor:Intel Dual-Core 3GHz or AMD Dual-Core Athlon 3GHz or faster Memory:4 GB RAM Graphics:NVIDIA GeForce 9800GT or ATI Radeon 5850 with Shader Model 3 and 1024 MB VRAM or faster DirectX®:dx90c Hard Drive:20 GB HD space Sound:DirectX 9.0c compatible audio-card Other Requirements:Broadband Internet connection

reviews.review_text: I don't understand why there are so many negative comments on the game, I've played Microsoft Flight Simulator X and Longbow II as well as Take on Helicopters, and all have their strengths and weaknesses, but this game felt like I was actually learning to fly a helicopter as some of the fast paced missions stumped me for a bit, but with persistence and saving at key points, it has been a very good experience.  Should I play this?: If you enjoyment of being immersed in a good story, and upgrading the various helicopters to take on more missions, this will not disappoint. The military sims are enjoyable, and definitely challenging, but seem to hurry past the learning to fly and focus more on combat. There is a good mix of civilian, transport, and law enforcement/military missions which allow you to earn money and buy all the upgrades, there can be an issue if you sell a helicopter you need, so picking up extra missions is helpful. I would do often walk around inspections of each heli before taking on a mission to significantly lower the repair bill.  Realism: Without a doubt, this is the most realistic feeling physics in a flight simulator I've played to date. With flight Simulator X I almost feel the helis were an afterthought addition because it lacks certain flight physics that require the constant adjustments required to keep the helicopters in flight. In Take On Helicopters, the wind and added weight of personnel and cargo changes how the helicopters fly, the copters accrue damage and can feel like a rickety bucket of bolts, giving an impending doom feeling before they ultimately reach maximum entropy and fall out of the sky. I had more than a few instances where I killed the Huey because I failed to properly finesse them through the trial without burying the throttle and burning out the engine.  Bugs: Every simulator has it's glitches, I've seen more glitches in Flight Sim X than I have in TOH. Only one instance have I seen a glitch and pressed escape, then selected skip in the menu.
I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone. Only to people who love to fly a helicopter with a bit more realism. And it's doing a decent job.

Bit of a cautious thumbs up, I got this game really cheap in a bundle quite some time ago. Played for a few mins, had awful performance issues and the controls were abysmal on a 360 pad...  Fast forward a little while and I bought a HOTAS stick and throttle along with a better graphics card. The difference was astounding. There was still another little issue though - using the hat switch for headlook is horrible. Fast forward a little more time and I got my hands on an EDtracker head tracking device. This was the final piece of the puzzle! With reliable head tracking and a half decent stick setup the game really begins to shine and also opened my eyes to a much more immersive experience in Arma 2/ Day Z mod.  Anybody familiar with BI games knows what to expect, a diamond with little bits of ♥♥♥♥ on it :D TOH is no exception, god awful voice acting and the usual performance issues on lower end hardware but with a little forum scouring you can maximize the experience you will have with a bit of tinkering.  *For anyone using high DPI settings in windows you will have end up with the missing mouse pointer bug. THIS is what completely did my head in with the game for a looong time, persevering with the methods needed to do any menu clicking (like starting a damn game session) especially graphics setup was a royal pain in the ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥. I found the solution to this from a completely different game but the solution works here also. Turn your DPI from 150 to 149 and your mouse will magically reappear :)

This is one of the worst games I've ever bought, and I'm a big ArmA player and fan.   It's amazing to me that this game has been out since 2011 and it's clearly unfinished. Let's start with the Seattle map. It's a screen print from Google earth with a few hills and buildings. On one mission for the campaign you have to fly to a number of golf courses; one of which has a flat, screen print club house! The AI cars driving on the map are non-collidible. You can drive through all of them. The motorboat has no engine sound. The fps is absolutely appalling - even worse than ArmA 2 OA... The campaign script is naive and poorly written, the characters laughable and badly acted.  The flight mechanics are reasonably good. It's quite like ArmA 3 advanced controls. You don't fly around with your finger firmly pushed on the collective like in ArmA 2. You have to add and subtract torgue or lose control. This I rather like.  The buildings, as one can expect are mainly from ArmA 2 and A2OA.  If only BI knew how to optimize and game engine or would at least employ some people who did, this would be a start.  I can not recommend this game, I'm afraid. It's just too shoddy and unfinished.
